comment.author: 71861129@N00
comment._content: Not a railway station, a sports arena, convention center, and exhibition hall.

comment.author: 73286033@N00
comment._content: This is the second building with that name, and was located on Wabash Avenue, between 14th and 16th Streets until it was demolished in the 1980's. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago_Coliseum

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: The 1912 Progressive Party ("Bull Moose") Convention was held at this same venue in August. It nominated former President Teddy Roosevelt for President and Governor Hiram Johnson of California for Vice President. Woodrow Wilson, a Democrat, won the election in November.

comment.author: 24075091@N00
comment._content:
The Google Maps marker for the Coliseum is incorrect.  It shows the Coliseum as between 16th and 18th Streets, but it was actually on the east side of Wabash between 14th and 16th Streets (per the Wikipedia article).  A Buddhist center called Soka Gakka International and its parking lots are now on the site.

Coliseum Park (which commemorates the Coliseum) is located acros the street on the southwest corner of 14th Place and Wabash.

comment.author: 29858426@N03
comment._content: Why are these great old buildings demolished? These are our heritage.

comment.author: 16974840@N02
comment._content: In the 60s I went to a civil rights rally there. Was anyone else there?

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: Hmmm . . . . Must have been at least someone else there, for it to be a proper rally. Didn't you see them?

comment.author: 25919039@N00
comment._content: I think that is Old St. Mary's church ...

comment.author: 94077197@N05
comment._content: This was once Libby Prison in Richmond Virginia.  Yes they actually dismantled and moved it. Most of the original prison was torn down over time but the castellated front wall remained until the entire structure was torn down in 1982.   Part of the Libby facade was given to the Chicago History Museum.
